Hi Sage! For the zucchini noodle lasagna, you can easily make a homemade vegan ricotta by blending soaked cashews, firm tofu, nutritional yeast, lemon juice, garlic, and a pinch of salt. It's very similar to the store-bought one I used. For the chili and cauliflower-based mac and cheese, you can replace the cheese with nutritional yeast or a vegan cheese alternative. Vegan cheeses are widely available in stores, or you can make your own by blending soaked cashews, lemon juice, and spices. This should give your dishes a rich, creamy texture without using dairy products. I hope this helps!

"Hi Maricela, I'm intrigued by the aquafaba you mentioned! Could you tell me more about its taste, texture, and how it functions as an egg substitute in baking? I'd love to learn more about this fascinating ingredient and how it can help those with dietary restrictions. Thank you!

"Aquafaba is the liquid from cooking chickpeas or from canned chickpeas! Its taste is quite neutral, and it can be used as an egg substitute in baking, giving structure and moisture to recipes. When whipped, it mimics the volume and texture of egg whites, perfect for meringues, mousses, and even some baked goods. I'm sure you'll find it fascinating!"

Here's the vegan hollandaise sauce recipe using aquafaba. You'll need aquafaba, lemon juice, non-dairy milk, nutritional yeast, turmeric, salt, and pepper. In a saucepan, combine 1/4 cup of aquafaba, 2 tbsp of lemon juice, and 1/4 cup of non-dairy milk. Bring to a simmer over medium heat. Whisk in 3 tbsp of nutritional yeast, a pinch of turmeric for color, and salt and pepper to taste. Cook, stirring constantly, until the sauce thickens. Let it cool, and it's ready to serve!
